questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was brought to the medicine clinic with complaints of headache with joint and muscle pains. Physical examination revealed nuchal rigidity and a petechial rash on the lower extremities. A Gram stain of her spinal fluid showed many neutrophils and many gram-negative, bean-shaped diplococci. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for the therapy of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms and lab results indicate that she was most likely suffering from meningitis due to N. meningitidis.
  • In this disease, the preferred treatments are penicillin G and a third-generation cephalosporin (mainly ceftriaxone).

Option A, C & D: All of these agents are not preferred for Meningococcal meningitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Meningitis caused by N. Meningitides, the preferred treatments are penicillin G and a third generation cephalosporin (mainly ceftriaxone).

questions.text: A 56-year-old female came to medicine opd with complaints of cough and sore throat. She was prescribed different medicines to curb the symptoms, following which she came back with a maculo-papular rash over arms & legs as given in the below image. Which of the following drug is most likely implicated for these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Penicillins:

Penicillin G is one of the most nontoxic antibiotics; up to 20 MU has been injected in a day without any organ toxicity.

Local irritancy and direct toxicity

  • Pain at i.m. Injection site,
  • Nausea on oral ingestion and
  • Thrombophlebitis of an injectedvein are dose-related expressions of irritancy.
  • Accidental i.v. injection of procaine penicillin produces CNS stimulation, hallucinations and convulsions due to procaine.

Hypersensitivity:

Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin reactions.Frequent manifestations of penicillin allergy are:

  • Rash,
  • Itching,
  • Urticaria
  • Fever

Wheezing, angioneurotic edema, serum sickness and exfoliative dermatitisare less common.

Anaphylaxis is rare (1 to 4 per 10,000 patients), but may be fatal.


Option A & D: These drugs can be used to prevent/manage allergic reactions.

Option B: Salbutamol does not cause allergic reactions instead, it is associated with muscle tremor and tachycardia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin Hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 19-year-old military recruit living in the army barracks develops a severe headache, photophobia and a stiff neck, prompting a visit to the emergency room. A lumbar puncture reveals a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. Which of the following cephalosporins is most likely to be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that has excellent CNS penetration. All the third-generation cephalosporins enter the CNS.

Ceftriaxone:


Penetration into CSF is good and elimination occurs equally in urine and bile.

Ceftriaxone has shown high efficacy in a wide range of serious infections including

  • Bacterial meningitis (especially in children),
  • Multiresistant typhoid fever,
  • Complicated urinary tract infections,
  • Abdominal sepsis and
  • Septicaemia.

Specific adverse effects

  • Hypoprothrombinemia
  • Bleeding

Ceftriaxone is the first choice drug for

  • Gonorrhoea
  • Salmonellosis (including typhoid),
  • Coli sepsis
  • Proteus
  • Serratia
  • Haemophilus
  • Empirical therapy for bacterial meningitis.

Option A: Cefazolin is the drug of choice for surgical prophylaxis.

Option B: Cefuroxime attains higher CSF levels as compared to other second generation cephalosporins. It can be used for bacterial meningitis. However, ceftriaxone is preferred.

Option D: Cefepime is fourth generation cephalosporin, it possesses activity against gram negative organisms (including Pseudomonas) resistant to 3rd generation cephalosporins.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that has excellent CNS penetration hence can be used empirically for Bacterial meningitis.

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic woman presents to the emergency room with signs and symptoms of urinary tract infection, including fever, dysuria and bacteriuria. Given that she is diabetic, she is admitted for treatment with intravenous ciprofloxacin. Which of the following is the most accurate mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin is a quinolone, a group of antibiotics that inhibit bacterial topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase).


Option A: The antibiotic classes that inhibit the 30S ribosome include aminoglycosides and tetracycline.

Option B: Inhibitors of the 50S ribosome include chloramphenicol, erythromycin, and clindamycin.

Option C: Bacterial cell wall inhibitors include penicillins, cephalosporins, and vancomycin.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ciprofloxacin is a quinolone, a group of antibiotics that inhibit bacterial topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase).

questions.text: An infant brought to paediatric ICU with complaints of development of jaundice just after birth and had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. Which of the following drug the mother might have taken during the third trimester of her pregnancy for this side effect to occur?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Co-trimoxazole:


  • Cotrimoxazole should not be given during pregnancy: Trimethoprim being an antifolate, there is theoretical teratogenic risk. Neonatal haemolysis and methemoglobinemia can occur if it is given near term.
  • Kernicterus may be precipitated in the newborn, especially premature, whose blood-brain barrier is more permeable, by displacement of bilirubin from plasma protein binding sites(As in this case)
  • Patients with renal disease may develop uremia.
  • A high incidence (upto 50%) of fever, rash and bone marrow hypoplasia has been reported among AIDS patients with Pneumocystis jirovecii infection when treated with high dose cotrimoxazole.
  • Diuretics given with cotrimoxazole have produced a higher incidence of thrombocytopenia.

Option A & C: Ampicillin and azithromycin can be safely given to pregnant females.

Option D: Chloramphenicol should be avoided in pregnancy due to availability of better antimicrobial agents.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cotrimoxazole should not be given during pregnancy because of the risk of Kernicterus to be precipitated in the newborn.

questions.text: A 27-year-old intravenous drug abuser is admitted for fever and shortness of breath. Multiple blood cultures drawn demonstrate S. aureus. The cultures further suggest resistance to methicillin. The attending physician also orders a transesophageal echocardiogram that shows tricuspid vegetations consistent with endocarditis. Which of the following is an appropriate antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Vancomycin is the drug of choice for serious infections due to methicillin- resistant S. aureus (MRSA).

In the case of endocarditis, the treatment is usually 6 weeks.

The resistance of MRSA is often due to altered penicillin-binding proteins, not beta-lactamases, so aztreonam, imipenem, and ceftriaxone would not be useful.

Gentamicin is often used in conjunction with penicillins in a non-MRSA setting


Option A & B: Aztreonam & imipenem would not be useful because of the altered penicillin-binding proteins in MRSA.

Option C: Gentamicin is used in conjunction with penicillins in non-MRSA cases. But not effective in MRSA cases.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for serious infections due to methicillin- resistant S. aureus (MRSA).

questions.text: A 72-year-old female was admitted to the hospital because of steadily declining urine output over the past 3 days. The woman had been receiving an antibiotic for 2 weeks to treat a urinary tract infection, apparently due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa. A urinalysis showed albuminuria, hematuria and hyaline casts. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
The patient's urinalysis indicates nephrotoxicity. Aminoglycoside antibiotics are active against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can cause nephrotoxicity in patients receiving these drugs for more than 1 week.

Nephrotoxicity

  • It manifests as tubular damage resulting in loss of urinary concentrating power, low g.f.r., nitrogen retention, albuminuria and casts.
  • Aminoglycosides attain high concentration in the renal cortex (proximal tubules).
  • Toxicity is related to the total amount of the drug received by the patient.
  • Renal toxicity is more in the elderly and in those with preexisting kidney disease.
  • An important implication of aminoglycoside- induced nephrotoxicity is reduced clearance of the antibiotic resulting in higher and more persistent blood levels, causing enhanced ototoxicity.
  • Streptomycin is the least nephrotoxic aminoglycoside.

Option A: Piperacillin is an Ureidopenicillins possess activity against gram negative rods including Pseudomonas. These are used with beta lactamase inhibitors and with aminoglycosides.

Main toxicity is hypersensitivity including serum sickness. Anaphylaxis is most commonly associated with these drugs

Option C: Aztreonam is active against β-lactamase producing gram negative rods including pseudomonas but has no activity against gram positive organisms or anaerobes.

It is the only beta lactam antibiotic that can be used in patients having severe allergy to penicillins or cephalosporins (as it is not cross allergenic).

Option D: vancomycin can cause RED MAN SYNDROME (diffuse flushing due to histamine release), chills, ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

Key Takeaway

  • Aminoglycoside antibiotics are active against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and can cause nephrotoxicity in patients receiving these drugs for more than 1 week

questions.text: A child was brought to paediatric department with complaints of infection and later he was treated by giving some antibiotics following which he again presented with polyuria, weakness and fever. On the basis of investigations he was found to be suffering from Fanconi syndrome. A history of taking some old left over antibiotic capsules was obtained. Which of the following antibiotic could be implicated causing these effects?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Tetracycline

Organ toxicity

Liver damage

  • Fatty infiltration of liver and jaundice occurs occasionally. Tetracyclines are risky in pregnant women; can precipitate fatal acute hepatic necrosis.

Kidney damage

  • Patients with kidney disease run the risk of tetracycline-induced kidney damage.
  • A reversible Fanconi syndrome like condition is produced by outdated and degraded tetracyclines (damage proximal tubules)

Phototoxicity

  • A sunburn-like or other severe skin reaction on exposed parts is seen in some individuals.

Teeth and bones

  • Tetracyclines have chelating property.
  • Calcium-tetracycline chelate gets deposited in developing teeth and bone. Brown discolouration, ill-formed teeth which are more susceptible to caries are produced.

Option B, C & D: All of these agents are not associated with development of fanconi syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

  • Reversible Fanconi syndrome like condition is produced by outdated and degraded tetracyclines (damage proximal tubules)

questions.text: A 34-year-old man brought to the medicine department seeking treatment with atypical pneumonia from Legionella pneumophila. He later is placed on an antibiotic by his physician that acts by inhibiting bacterial peptidyl transferase. Administration of large doses of this agent is typically associated with which of the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
• Legionnaire disease is usually treated with a macrolide such as erythromycin.
  • Large intravenous doses of this drug may cause reversible tinnitus and hearing loss.

Option A, B & D: All of these side effects are not associated with Macrolide infusion.

Key Takeaway:

  • Large intravenous doses of macrolide may cause reversible tinnitus and hearing loss.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a rash on the palms and soles of his feet as well as fever and headache. He was camping last weekend and admits to being bitten by a tick. His Weil-Felix test result is positive, suggesting Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following is the most suitable antibiotic that should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline, a tetracycline (30S ribosome inhibitor), is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease.

Option A, B & C: All of these given agents are not the preferred drug for Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

Key Takeaway

  • Doxycycline is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was HIV positive presented with a fever of 100.8° with profuse night sweats, poor appetite and a weight loss over the past 5 months. Physical examination revealed a cachectic female with prominent oral thrush and mild splenomegaly. Her CD4+ lymphocyte count was very low at 45 cells/mm3 and a DNA probe test confirmed the diagnosis of Mycobacterium avium complex infection. An appropriate multidrug regimen was started. Which of the following drugs was most likely included in the patient's pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
• MAC infection is common in end-stage AIDS patients, and the risk of developing the infection is the highest when the CD4+ lymphocyte count is less than 50 cells/mm3, as in this case.
  • MAC is much less susceptible than Mycobacterium tuberculosis to most antimycobacterial drugs, and in most cases disseminated MAC is incurable and therapy is lifelong.
  • Drug regimens for MAC should include at least three drugs, and one of these must be a macrolide, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin.
  • Other drugs active against MAC are rifampin, ethambutol, ethionamide, imipenem and fluoroquinolones.

Options A, B & C: All of the given agents are not used in MAC infections.

Key Takeaway:

  • Drug regimens for MAC should include at least three drugs, and one of these must be a macrolide, such as clarithromycin or azithromycin.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of borderline leprosy was receiving multi drug therapy (MDT). Later, he developed skin lesions and presented to the dermatologist with features shown in the figure below. What should be the treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Reactions in leprosy

Lepra reaction

  • This occurs in LL, usually coincides with the institution of chemotherapy and/or intercurrent infection.
  • It is a Jarisch Herxheimer (Arthus) type of reaction due to release of antigens from the killed bacilli, and may be mild, severe or life-threatening, i.e. erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL).
  • Temporary discontinuation of dapsone is recommended only in severe cases.
  • Clofazimine (200 mg daily) is effective in controlling the reaction (except the severe one), probably because of its anti-inflammatory property.
  • For severe reaction, prednisolone 40-60 mg/day is started immediately and continued until the reaction subsides. The dose is then tapered over 2-3 months

Reversal reaction

  • This is seen in TT and BL cases, and is a manifestation of delayed hypersensitivity to M. leprae antigens.
  • Cutaneous ulceration, multiple nerve involvement with swollen, painful and tender nerves occur suddenly even after completion of therapy.
  • Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as ENL, but thalidomide is ineffective.

Option A & C: MDT is not stopped in Lepra reaction, hence false options.

Option B: Lepra reaction is treated with Steroids hence thalidomide is incorrect option.

Key Takeaway:

  • Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as Erythema nodosum leprosum

questions.text: A 56-year-old man diagnosed with bone tuberculosis started a multidrug treatment but 4 months later, the disease was minimally improved and susceptibility testing showed a complete resistance to isoniazid. A high level of resistance of tubercle bacilli to isoniazid involves a decrease in the activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
• Isoniazid is a prodrug that must be converted into the active compound by a mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase.
  • Resistance is often associated with the deletion of the katG gene that codes for the synthesis of catalase peroxidase. In this way, activation of the prodrug cannot occur.

Isoniazid (H)

  • It is a prodrug activated by catalase-peroxidase (coded by KatG).
  • Active metabolite inhibits the enzyme ketoenoylreductase (coded by inh A), required for mycolic acid synthesis
  • It acts by O2 dependent pathway such as catalase peroxidase reaction.
  • It is bacteriostatic against resting and bactericidal against rapidly multiplying organisms.
  • It is effective against intra- as well as extra-cellular
  • Action is marked most against rapidly multiplying bacilli (less effective against slow multipliers).
  • It is widely distributed in the body and has maximum CSF penetration.
  • It is effective orally and metabolized by ACETYLATION which is genetically controlled.
  • It is an essential component of multi-drug therapy of tuberculosis and is drug of choice (used solely) for prophylaxis of tuberculosis and for treatment of latent tuberculosis infection.
  • Resistance occurs due to mutation in Kat G (gene for catalse-peroxidase) or inhA.
  • Mutation in kat G is responsible for high level resistance whereas mutation in inhA confers cross resistance to ethionamide.

Key Takeaway:

  • Resistance to isoniazid occurs due to mutation in Kat G (gene for catalase-peroxidase) or inhA.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought to the emergency department by her mother, who said that her daughter had a high fever and was irritable and lethargic. Physical examination showed nuchal rigidity and a positive Brudzinski sign. Subsequent exams led to the diagnosis of meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following drugs would have been appropriate prophylaxis for the health personnel assisting this girl?
questions.solution:
• Rifampin is the drug of first choice for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis.
  • The potential for a close contact to become infected with Neisseria meningitidis is 500 to 800 times greater than for the total population.
  • The drug should be administered as soon as possible because the risk of secondary disease is greatest within 2 to 5 days after exposure to the index case.
  • Other drugs used for chemoprophylaxis include ceftriaxone and ciprofloxacin.

Options A, B & C: All of the given agents are not preffered drugs of choice for prophylaxis of close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Rifampin is the drug of first choice for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of patients with meningococcal meningitis.

choices.text: Add pyrazinamide to the current therapy

questions.text: A 66-year-old man recently diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis started a three-drug treatment with isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol. The man, who had been suffering from atrial fibrillation for 4 years, was currently being treated with propranolol and warfarin. Which of the following changes in the patient's therapeutic regimen would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
• Rifampicin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of many drugs, including glucocorticoids, oral contraceptives, methadone, β-blockers, and warfarin.
  • Therefore, the dose of warfarin should be increased to maintain an appropriate anticoagulant effect.

Interactions

Rifampicin is a microsomal enzyme inducer-increases several CYP450

isoenzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP1A2 and CYP2C subfamily.

  • It thus enhances its own metabolism (area under the plasma concentration-time curve is reduced by ~35%) as well as that of many drugs like
  • Warfarin
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Corticosteroids
  • Sulfonylureas
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs)
  • Theophylline
  • Metoprolol
  • Fluconazole
  • Ketoconazole
  • Clarithromycin
  • Phenytoin

Contraceptive failures have occurred. It is advisable to switch over to an oral contraceptive containing a higher dose (50 μg) of estrogen or use an alternative method of contraception.

Other Options:

Key Takeaway:

  • Rifampicin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of warfarin, hence dose of warfarin should be increased to maintain an appropriate anticoagulant effect.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented to the hospital complaining of anorexia, nausea and vomiting, and abdominal discomfort. He also had pain on motion and stiffness in several joints. The man, recently diagnosed with renal tuberculosis, started a four-drug combination regimen 1 month ago. Lab results showed serum aspartate aminotransferase of 280 U/L and serum uric acid of 25 mg /dL. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient symptoms and signs?
questions.solution:
• The gastrointestinal symptoms and the high aminotransferase levels (which suggest some liver dysfunction), together with the joint pain and hyperuricemia, strongly indicate that pyrazinamide is the drug that caused these adverse effects.
  • Hepatotoxicity is the major limiting adverse effect of pyrazinamide, is dose-related, and is far less common today with current dosing regimens.
  • Arthralgia is also common and dose-related.
  • Hyperuricemia is seen in more than 50% of patients taking the drug and is likely due to inhibition of uric acid secretion.

Option A: Rifampicin is also hepatotoxic and may cause skin rash, flu like syndrome and anemia. Hepatotoxicity due to rifampicin is uncommon without pre-existing liver disease. It presents as hyperbilirubinemia

Option C: Isoniazid causes peripheral neuritis. It is also hepatotoxic and can cause hemolysis in G-6 PD deficient patients.

Option D: Streptomycin is not hepatotoxic.

Key Takeaway:

  • Hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia are the major limiting adverse effect of pyrazinamide

questions.text: A 68-year-old man hospitalized because of prostate cancer developed high grade fever 4 days after prostatectomy despite empirical antibacterial therapy. He had a urinary catheter and was treated with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient had been suffering from chronic renal insufficiency for the past year. Urinalysis showed many budding yeasts and cultures that were positive for Candida albicans. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for systemic antifungal treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from candiduria, a condition often related to the placement of an indwelling urinary catheter, especially if the patient is taking broad-spectrum antibiotics, as in this case.

Eradication of Candida in the urine includes the removal of the catheter and an antifungal treatment.

Treatment options include amphotericin B, fluconazole and an echinocandin such as caspofungin.

However, in this patient, amphotericin B, which directly damages renal tubules, is contraindicated because of chronic renal dysfunction.

Echinocandins are the newest class of antifungal drugs. They act by inhibiting the synthesis of β-glucan, an essential constituent of the fungal cell wall.

Their antifungal spectrum is limited to Candida and Aspergillus species.

Echinocandins are approved for treatment of mucocutaneous or disseminated candidiasis.

ANTIFUNGAL DRUGS


Option A: Amphotericin B, which directly damages renal tubules, is contraindicated because of chronic renal dysfunction in this patient.

Option C & D: Griseofulvin & Nystatin are used in dermatophytosis and Oropharyngeal Candidiasis Respectively. They have no role in the management of Candiduria. Treatment options include amphotericin B, fluconazole and an echinocandin such as caspofungin.

Key Takeaway:

  • Echinocandins are approved for treatment of mucocutaneous or disseminated candidiasis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient developed COVID-19 pneumonia and was treated accordingly. Few months later, patient presented with nasal congestion, sinusitis and swelling of face. There were black lesions on the nose bridge. On CT scan diagnosis of mucormycosis was made. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B can be applied topically for oral, vaginal and cutaneous candidiasis, fungal corneal ulcer and otomycosis.

It is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.

However, because of higher toxicity of AMB, the azole antifungals are now preferred in conditions where their efficacy approaches that of AMB.

In serious fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, initial induction therapy with AMB may be replaced by the alternative safer azole antifungal drug for continuation of therapy.

Febrile neutropenia: Empirical use of i.v. AMB is often made in neutropenic patients whose fever is not responding to i.v. bactericidal antibiotics.

Leishmaniasis: AMB is the most effective drug for resistant cases of kala azar and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis


Option A, B & D: All of these given agents are not the preferred drug for mucormycosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Amphotericin B is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is placed on an antifungal agent for systemic infection. He is noted to have decreased serum leukocyte and platelet counts. Bone marrow suppression is a common adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow suppression is a common adverse effect of flucytosine.

Flucytosine (5-FC) is a narrow spectrum fungistatic, active against Cryptococcus neoformans, Torula, Chromoblastomyces; and a few strains of Candida.

Adverse effects Flucytosine (5-FC)

Toxicity of 5-FC consists of

  • Dose-dependent bone marrow depression
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances, particularly enteritis and diarrhoea.
  • Liver dysfunction is mild and reversible.

Use

  • In cryptococcosis (both meningeal and non-meningeal) its synergistic action with AMB is utilized to reduce the total dose of the more toxic latter drug.

Option A: Fluconazole causes nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, rash and headache.

Option C: Griseofulvin causes gastrointestinal disturbances, photosensitivity and liver dysfunction. It can also cause disulfiram-like reactions with alcohol.

Option D: Terbinafine causes rash and gastrointestinal upset.

Key Takeaway:

  • Bone marrow suppression is a common adverse effect of flucytosine.

questions.text: A 38-year-old HIV patient presents with seizures and neck rigidity. The CSF examination shows the presence of organisms on India ink and a diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. Which of the following antifungal drug is used for initial treatment of this meningitis?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B can be applied topically for oral, vaginal and cutaneous candidiasis, fungal corneal ulcer and otomycosis.

It is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.

However, because of higher toxicity of AMB, the azole antifungals are now preferred in conditions where their efficacy approaches that of AMB.

In serious fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, initial induction therapy with AMB may be replaced by the alternative safer azole antifungal drug for continuation of therapy.


Key Takeaway:

  • Amphotericin B is the most effective drug for practically all types of systemic mycoses and is the gold standard of antifungal therapy.
